c74object.name: bach.circle
c74object.description: The purpose of bach.circle is to act as a simple clock diagram, where each point can represent any abstract concept as pitch-classes or rhythmic positions on a looped grid. Each point may have a velocity also. Some of the points can be selected, thus representing for instance pitch-class sets ("chords" or "scales"...) or rhythmic patterns.

inlet.digest: Points, or a 2-depth list of interlaced Points and Velocities

outlet.digest: Points, as a plain list of point indices
bang when changed via the interface
outlet.description: A bang is output whenever the user changes the diagram via mouse and keyboard

method.name: (keyboard)
method.description:
• Cmd+T (mac) or Ctrl+T (win): Transpose (rotate) 1 step clockwise
• Cmd+R (mac) or Ctrl+R (win): Transpose (rotate) 1 step counterclockwise
• Cmd+C (mac) or Ctrl+C (win): Take the complement
• Cmd+I (mac) or Ctrl+I (win): Invert with respect to vertical axis
• Cmd+Shift+D (mac) or Ctrl+Shift+D (win): Dump (output modulo, velocities and points)

method.name: (mouse)
method.digest: Add/delete points, or change their velocities
method.description:
• click: Add a point
• Alt+click: Output clicked point index, in the form point pt, where pt is as usual the point index.
• Cmd+click (mac) or Ctrl+click (win): Delete a point
• Ctrl+click+drag (mac) or Shift+Ctrl+click+drag (win): Change the velocity of a point (dragging up or down)
• Ctrl+Alt+click+drag (mac) or Shift+Ctrl+Alt+click+drag (win): Change the modulo (dragging up or down)

method.name: add
method.description:
Syntax: add <llll: points>
Examples:
• add 2 4 5 → add some points
• add (2 60) (4 100 (5 120) → add some points with their velocities
Add a point to the diagram. The argument can be, as in the standard llll method, either a plain list (representing point indices) or an interlaced list (pt1 vel1) (pt2 vel2)... representing points and velocities
See also:delete

method.name: clear
method.description: Clear all the points of the diagram

method.name: complement
method.description:
Get the complement of the existing diagram, i.e. the one formed by all the point which were not in the original diagram. The velocities of such complemented points are assigned by default.
See also:invert,transpose

method.name: delete
method.description:
Syntax: delete <llll: points>
Example: delete 2 4 5 → delete some points
Delete some points from the diagram (from their indices).

method.name: dump
int
method.description: In the third inlet, an integer sets the modulo (number of points in the clock).

method.name: invert
method.description:
Mirror ("invert") all the points with respect to the vertical axis drawn by the center and the upper point (0).
See also:transpose,complement

method.name: llll
method.digest: Set points and/or velocities (depending on inlet)
method.description:
In first inlet: a plain list sets the points: each point is given as per its index, 0 being the upper one, and then clockwise. An interlaced such as [(pt1 vel1) (pt2 vel2)...] sets both points and velocities.
In second inlet: Sets the velocities for the points you'll send in the first inlet later.

method.name: transpose
method.description:
Syntax: transpose <int: amount>
Examples:
• transpose 3 → rotate of 3 steps clockwise
• transpose -3 → rotate of 1 steps counterclockwise
Rotate ("transpose") all the points in the diagram of a given amout, given in steps: a positive amount will rotate clockwise, a negative one will rotate counterclockwise.
See also:invert,complement

attribute.name: autoreduce
attribute.description: Automatically delete duplicates of points (if two or more points with the same index, up to the modulo, were defined).

attribute.name: bgcolor
attribute.description: Diagram external background color

attribute.name: bordercolor
attribute.description: Color of the diagram border

attribute.name: circlebordercolor
attribute.description: Color of the diagram circle outline

attribute.name: circleinnercolor
attribute.description: Inner color of the diagram circle

attribute.name: circlelinewidth
attribute.description: Width of the line of the main circle in the diagram, in pixels

attribute.name: inset
attribute.description: Inset of the clock diagram with respect to the border, in pixels

attribute.name: linewidth
attribute.description: Width of the line linking all selected points together, in pixels

attribute.name: modulo
attribute.description: Modulo of the diagram (the number of steps in which the circle is divided)

attribute.name: modulotextcolor
attribute.description: Color of the modulo text.

attribute.name: names
attribute.description: Assign name to each point in the clock, instead of number. One can use this attribute to individually naming each point, e.g. by setting [names do do# re re# mi fa fa# sol sol# la sib si] and displaying latin notes instead of numbers.

attribute.name: numberstextcolor
attribute.description: Color of the numbers text.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: pointbordercolor
attribute.description: Color of each point's outline

attribute.name: pointinnercolor
attribute.description: Color of the inner part of each point.

attribute.name: pointlinewidth
attribute.description: Width of the line of each point's circle, in pixels

attribute.name: pointradius
attribute.description: Radius of each point in pixels

attribute.name: points
attribute.description: List of the selected points in the diagram.

attribute.name: selectedpointbordercolor
attribute.description: Color of the selected point's outline

attribute.name: selectioncolor
attribute.description: Color of the selected items and polygonal line.

attribute.name: sendnamesthroughdump
attribute.description: If names are defined, this attribute tells whether those names must be sent through the first outlet instead of point indices.

attribute.name: showfocus
attribute.description: Show that the object has the focus by increasing the width of the border.

attribute.name: showmodulo
attribute.description: Show the modulo in the middle of the diagram

attribute.name: shownumbers
attribute.description:
Attribute deciding when the numbers in the diagram must be shown (or the names, in case the names attribute is defined
Never: never show any number
Mouseover: Only show numbers when the mouse is over them
Selected: Only show numbers when the corresponding point is selected
Always: Always show all the numbers

attribute.name: showpolygon
attribute.description: Show the polygon linking all the selected numbers.

attribute.name: showvelocity
attribute.description:
Attribute deciding how the velocity of a point must be mapped visually: None: velocity must be graphically ignored
Colorscale: by changing the lightness of the point inner color
Colorspectrum: by changing the point inner color over a spectrum of colors (red to blue)
Alpha: by changing the alpha channel (transparent to full)
Circle Size: by changing the point circle size

attribute.name: velocities
attribute.description: List of the velocities corresponding to the selected points (on element for each of the defined points

c74object.discussion:
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.
A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.

entry.name: Inlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Points, or a 2-depth list of interlaced Points and Velocities.

entry.name: Outlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Points, as a plain list of point indices.

entry.name: Outlet 4 (bang)
entry.description: bang when changed via the interface. A bang is output whenever the user changes the diagram via mouse and keyboard

entry.name: More details
entry.description:
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.
A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.

entry.name: Keywords
entry.description: circle, diagram, clock, pitch-class, set, rhythm, loop, velocity, select, rotate, transpose, invert, microtone.
